choices.text: Uses a spoon and a fork

questions.text: A 15-month-old child is brought for a routine check-up. Which of the following developmental milestones is least likely to be achieved at this age?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Stacking 6 blocks is typically achieved by 2 years of age, whereas the other listed milestones are appropriate for 15 months.

Developmental Milestones:

questions.text: A child can walk up and down stairs without support, build a tower of six blocks, copy a straight line, brush teeth with help, put on clothes, and point to pictures in a book. What is the most likely developmental age of this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gross motor (walking up and down stairs), fine motor (stacking six blocks, copying line), personal-social (brushing teeth with help, dressing), and language (picture identification) all align with typical 2-year-old developmental milestones.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with delayed speech, poor motor coordination, and limited social interaction. The developmental assessment shows delays in both language and fine motor skills. The child has not yet been diagnosed with intellectual disability. What is the most likely diagnosis at this stage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child is under 5 years with delays in multiple developmental domains (language and motor). This fits the definition of Global Developmental Delay (GDD), used when a child shows delays in two or more areas.

Global Developmental Delay (GDD):

  • GDD describes young children (under 5 years) with delays in multiple developmental domains who do not yet meet criteria for Intellectual Disability (ID).
  • DSM-5 Diagnostic Criteria: GDD is diagnosed in children <5 years of age who show significant delay (≥2 SDs below the mean) in two or more of the following developmental domains:
    • Receptive and expressive language
    • Gross and fine motor skills
    • Cognitive development
    • Social and personal development
    • Activities of daily living
  • Delay in two domains often correlates with delays across all domains, including cognitive and intellectual abilities.
  • Prognosis:
    • Up to 80% of children with early GDD continue to show developmental challenges into school-age years.
    • However, not all children with early GDD are later diagnosed with ID.
  • Use of GDD Term in Severe Delays: In children with severe early delays, the term GDD may continue to be used even beyond age 5, especially when:
    • There are persistently low developmental quotients
    • Multiple assessments show significant impairment
    • The child shows minimal response to interventions in the early years

Explanation of other options:

Autism Spectrum Disorder (Option A): Although social delay is noted, the absence of restricted and repetitive behaviours makes autism less likely based on current information.

Intellectual Disability (Option B) is usually diagnosed after age 5 when cognitive and adaptive deficits are consistently evident over time, which hasn't been established here.

Developmental Coordination Disorder (Option D) typically involves only motor coordination issues, without accompanying delays in language or social development.

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student presents with episodes of eating large amounts of junk food rapidly, followed by self-induced vomiting. She reports feeling guilty and ashamed after these episodes. She has a history of frequent dieting and is currently slightly overweight. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Clinical history of binge eating followed by vomiting, guilt, and a history of dieting in an overweight adolescent points toward bulimia nervosa.

Explanation of other options:

Pica (Option B): Involves the persistent ingestion of non-nutritive substances like soil or paint, which is not described in this case.

Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder (ARFID) (Option C): Characterised by food avoidance due to sensory issues or fear (e.g., choking), without binge eating, purging, or body image concerns.

choices.text: Retentive encopresis due to chronic constipation

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with repeated staining of his underwear over the past several months. His parents report that he skips bowel movements for several days, followed by passage of small amounts of stool multiple times per day. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen and a palpable faecal mass in the left lower quadrant. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario of stool withholding, overflow soiling, and a palpable faecal mass strongly points toward retentive encopresis.

Encopresis (Soiling):

  • Involuntary or intentional passage of faeces into clothing.
  • Seen in children with developmental age ≥4 years.
  • Considered even in 3-year-olds who are not toilet trained.
  • Types:
    • Retentive Encopresis: Due to chronic constipation or faecal impaction.
    • Non-retentive Encopresis: Passage of normal stools into underwear, not associated with constipation.
  • Etiology:
    • Dietary issues
    • Slow gastrointestinal transit time due to neurologic or genetic factors
    • Chronic stool withholding (often due to painful defecation)
  • Clinical Features:
    • Uncontrolled defecation; parents may misinterpret it as diarrhoea.
    • Soiling may be frequent or continuous.
    • Often coexists with faecal impaction, painful defecation, or stool withholding.
  • Treatment:
    • Education: Explain condition, normalise process, avoid blame/punishment.
    • Disimpaction: High-dose PEG ± stimulant laxatives (e.g., Ex-Lax).
    • Maintenance: Soft stool regularity with PEG, sorbitol juices, and behavioural therapy.
    • Behavioural Training:
      • Timed toilet sitting.
      • Praise and positive reinforcement only.
      • Avoid punishment and embarrassment.

Explanation of other options:

Functional non-retentive faecal incontinence (Option A) is not associated with constipation or faecal retention; the child in the scenario has clear signs of chronic stool retention (e.g., faecal mass, abdominal distension).

Irritable bowel syndrome - constipation predominant (IBS-C) (Option B) typically presents with abdominal discomfort and constipation without faecal soiling, and it is rare in young children, especially with a faecal mass.

Early-onset inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) (Option D): IBD often causes bloody stools, weight loss, growth failure, and systemic symptoms, which are absent in this child.

choices.text: Tantrums occurring fewer than 5 times per day
Child remains irritable or upset between tantrums

questions.text: A 3½-year-old child throws tantrums involving crying and kicking 3-4 times a day. Each episode lasts 10 minutes, and the child is cheerful in between. Which of the following features would help distinguish abnormal from normal tantrums in such a child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Persistent negative mood between episodes suggests abnormal tantrums.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with persistent bedwetting at night. He has never achieved 6 months of nighttime dryness, has no daytime urinary symptoms, and physical examination is normal. Urinalysis is unremarkable. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is primary monosymptomatic nocturnal enuresis, and the enuresis alarm is the first-line treatment due to high long-term success and low relapse rates. Desmopressin offers rapid relief but is not first-line unless alarms fail or quick control is needed.

Enuresis:

  • Urinary incontinence in a developmentally mature child (usually beyond 5 years).
  • Types:
    • Monosymptomatic nocturnal enuresis (MNE): Nighttime bedwetting without other urinary symptoms.
    • Non-monosymptomatic: Associated with urinary symptoms (urgency, daytime wetting, etc.).
    • Primary: Never achieved 6 months of nighttime dryness.
    • Secondary: Recurrence after achieving 6 months of dryness.
  • Genetics: Higher risk if parents were affected (15% neither, 50% one, 75% both).
  • Possible causes:
    • Decreased nocturnal vasopressin surge → nocturnal polyuria.
    • Functional small bladder capacity.
    • Constipation → mechanical bladder compression.
    • High arousal threshold or altered sleep architecture.
    • Psychological stress → more linked with secondary
  • Clinical Evaluation:
    • History: Voiding patterns, fluid intake, constipation, family history.
    • Examination: Usually normal.
    • Urinalysis: To rule out UTI, diabetes mellitus/insipidus.
  • Treatment:
    • Parental education:
      • Reassure that it's involuntary and usually self-resolves.
      • Avoid punishment.
    • Behavioural measures:
      • Limit evening fluids.
      • Encourage frequent daytime voiding + pre-bedtime void.
      • Avoid caffeine/sugar drinks at night.
    • Enuresis alarm:
      • First-line for most; long-term success with low relapse.
    • Desmopressin:
      • Rapid effect (useful for sleepovers or emotional distress).
      • Reduces nocturnal urine production.

Explanation of other options:

Reassure and monitor only (Option A): Although reassurance is helpful, active intervention like an enuresis alarm is indicated in children over 5 years with persistent monosymptomatic nocturnal enuresis.

Start desmopressin immediately (Option B): Desmopressin may offer rapid symptom relief, but it is not first-line due to higher relapse rates and is best used when alarm therapy is ineffective or for temporary control.

Refer to a pediatric urologist (Option D): Referral is not needed in uncomplicated monosymptomatic enuresis with normal examination findings and urinalysis; it's reserved for daytime symptoms, recurrent UTIs, or alarm therapy failure.

choices.text: Insulin is important to control fetal growth
Human fetal growth is rapid in the first half of intrauterine life

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding human growth except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Option A is True.Human growth shows cephalo-caudal progression. This implies that head growth occurs earlier compared to neck and trunk growth, while arms grow earlier compared to legs.
  • Option B is False.Human growth proceeds from distal to proximal. Distal body parts like hands increase in size earlier than the arms.
  • Option C is True. As discussed in video lectures, fetal growth is controlled by multiple hormones. Among them,insulin is important for overall fetal size and weight.
  • Option D is True.Human fetal growth is rapid in the first half of the intrauterine life, and becomes relatively slower in the 2nd.
  • Fat depositionoccurs in 2nd half, but overall growth remains sluggish till it picks up rapidly postnatally.

questions.text: Match the correct pair based on the growth patterns of different tissues as shown in the graph:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is 1-A, 2-B, 3-D, 4-C.

questions.text: Fetal growth is maximally affected by which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Maximal fetal growth is mediated by insulin and its congeners like IGF-1 or somatomedins.

Also, remember that growth hormone plays a minimal role in utero but becomes an important mediator of growth post-natally.

choices.text: Development occurs in spurts rather than being a continuous process
CNS maturity is a major determinant of development
Primitive reflexes must be lost for complex milestones to be attained

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding developmental sequence in children, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Six rules of development in a child:

  • 1st: Development is a continuous process - Begins in utero. (Option A)
  • 2nd: CNS maturityis the major determinant. (Option B)
  • 3rd: Cephalo-caudal (Option C)
  • 4th: Primitive reflexesmust be lost. (Option D)
  • 5th: Initially, reflexes or milestones are general or crude. As age progresses, they become more complex
  • 6th: A similar sequence occurs in all children.

choices.text: Perinatal period - 26 weeks of gestation till 7 days post birth
School Age Child - 73 months to 12 years

questions.text: Identify the incorrect match of the period of growth and corresponding cut-off for ages.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The perinatal period is defined as 22 weeks of gestation to 7 days after birth, not 26 weeks.

choices.text: A baby born at 33 weeks - Late Preterm
A baby weighing 1300 g - Low Birthweight
A baby born at 41 weeks + 3 days - Late Term
A baby born at 298 days - Term Neonate

questions.text: Which of the following neonates is correctly matched with its gestational age classification?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

41 weeks + 3 days falls within the range of 41 to 41 weeks + 6 days, which defines a Late Term neonate.

choices.text: Birth weight is expected to triple by 6 months of age
Average length at 1 year of age is approximately 60 cm
Head circumference increases by 1 cm/month throughout the first year
An upper-to-lower segment ratio of 1.4:1 is normal at 1 year of age

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding normal growth parameters in infants and children?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

At 1 year of age, the normal upper-to-lower segment ratio is 1.4:1.

Growth Parameters:

questions.text: The weight of a child is quadrupled the birth weight at?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Weight of a child is quadrupled the birth weight by 24 months.

questions.text: A child has just started to move on all 4 limbs as shown below. When does the following movement begin in a child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The child being shown in the image is doing crawling, which begins at 8-9 months.In crawling, the abdomen is touching the ground.
  • Creeping, which involves the abdomen lifted off the ground, comes about 1 month later at 9-10 months.

questions.text: A child can repeat a sentence of 6 syllables at what age?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A 3-year-old child can use 250 words in vocabulary, can repeat 3 numbers and can repeat a sentence of 6 syllables.

choices.text: As much as the child wants

questions.text: Maximum screen time allowed by AAP & WHO for a child aged 2-5 years is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • According to WHO, children up to 24 months should avoid screen time (mobiles/laptops/TVs/Computers) completely, except for video-chatting.
  • But for children between2-5 years, up to 1 hour of screen time is allowed in the presence of the parents.

questions.text: Look at the image below and tell the approximate age at which this milestone is normally attained in a child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

As seen in the image, the child is crawling/creeping upstairs, which is normally attained at 15 months of age.

Remember the following milestones related to stair-walking

questions.text: Both the ability to run independently and the social behaviour of separation anxiety in a child are present together at what age?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A child can run stiffly but independently around 18 months of age. The child also develops separation anxiety, esp at night, when parents are not around, starting from 18 months of age. So the age at which both will be present together is at 18-20 months of age.

questions.text: Mouthing of objects tends to significantly reduce by what developmental age in a child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

At 6 months, as the ability to chew develops, the child can take a biscuit to his mouth and chew. At this age, he tends to mouth all objects offered to him.

This is called mouthing of objects and can be a reason for inadvertent foreign body ingestion or aspiration. This tendency abates by around 1 year of age in most children. According to other texts and sources, mouthing reduces between 12-18 months.

questions.text: A child with developmental delay can ride a tricycle, can copy a circle, can say their name, knows their sex, but cannot narrate a story. What is the developmental age?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The age of attaining milestones normally

  • Riding a tricycle normally comes at 3 years of age
  • Saying full name and genderalso comes at 3 years of age
  • Copying a circle comes at 3 years of age
  • Narrating a story comes at 4 years of age.

Now, in this question, the child can perform the milestones corresponding to 3 years, but is unable to do milestones related to 4 years. Hence, the developmental age of the child should be 3 years.

questions.text: Look at the image below and tell the approximate age at which this milestone is normally attained first in a child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child is walking upstairs with support, which comes at 18 months of age. Also, remember the following key milestones related to stair-walking

questions.text: A child keeps doing the following when awake. What is the age at which this disappears?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

As depicted in the image, the child is intently looking at his own hands. This is called as Hand Regard.

  • Hand regardnormally appears at 3 months, i.e., 12 weeks of age.
  • Normally disappears at 5 months, i.e., 20 weeks of age.
  • Persistence of hand regard beyond 20 weeks indicates a likely developmental delay in the child.
  • Hand regard is even present in children without vision.

questions.text: A child has recently learnt to copy the image as shown below. Assuming that the child's development is proceeding normally, what other things will the child be able to do at this age?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child can copy a plus sign, also called a Cross, at 4 years of age.

Since this child is able to make a cross just now & his development is normal, as mentioned, the likely age of the child is 4 years.

Singing a song normally comes at 4 years of age & is thus the correct answer.

Explanation of other options:

Tying of shoelaces (Option A) comes at 5 years of age

Asking the meaning of words (Option C) comes at 5 years of age

Identifying 4 different colours (Option D) comes at 5 years of age.

questions.text: A normal infant can sit leaning forward with hands, reach for and grasp a cube with one hand, transfer objects between hands, cannot wave bye-bye, and cannot hold objects between finger and thumb. Most probable age is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A normal infant can sit withtheir support from 6 months onwards, also known as the Tripod position.
  • Reaching for and grasping a cube with one hand,also called as Unidextrous grasp, comes at 6 months of age
  • Transferring objects hand to handdevelops between 6 to 7 months of age.
  • Waving bye-bye develops at 9 months
  • Immature Pincer grasp comes by 9 months and the mature one by 12 months.

So, the child can do milestones of at or before 7 months of age, but has not attained milestones related to 9 months and beyond. Hence, the probable age of the child is 7 months.

questions.text: A boy has now learnt to feed himself with a spoon without spillage, can dress and undress himself with supervision, and knows that he is a boy. These milestones are most likely developed between which ages?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Feeding oneself with a spoon with spillageis achieved by 15 months & without spillage by 18 months of age. Can undress self with assistance or supervision by 2 years of age.
  • Can dress self with assistance or supervision by 3 years of age.
  • Knowing gender comes by 3 years.
  • Hence best possible answer here is2 to 3 years.

questions.text: An infant can sit leaning forward on his own hands. When made to stand, he bounces actively. He laughs loudly, but becomes concerned when his mother moves away and a new person enters the house. What is his most likely age?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The child can sit with their support, laughs loudly and has stranger anxiety.
  • All of this is pointing towards a likely developmental age of 6-7 months.
  • Thus, the best answer is option D, i.e. 28 weeks.

questions.text: Handedness gets established at what age?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Handedness develops in a child at 3 years of age, i.e., 36 months of age.

questions.text: Which of the following is a known risk factor for language delay?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The cause of language delay is multifactorial. It can be due to biological factors, such as hearing loss or cognitive difficulties, autism, or environmental causes.
  • Children whose first-degree relatives have a history of language, speech, or reading delays are at greater risk for language disorders.
  • Other known risk factors include premature birth, male gender, and low socioeconomic status.
  • There isno evidence to support a relationship between speech delays and birth order, history of otitis media, or multilingual environments.

questions.text: A 15-month-old boy is brought to the urgent care centre after an episode during which he stopped breathing, turned blue, became limp, and stiffened. The episode lasted for about 1 minute, after which he was very sleepy. The boy had been playing in a park when he fell, scraped his knee, and immediately cried. He then became apneic, cyanotic, and limp; he lost consciousness. He has had no recent illness. There is no known family history of syncope, sudden death, or epilepsy. Of the following, based on this boy's history, the MOST likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child had a typical cyanotic variety of breath-holding spell, triggered by pain followed by crying.

  • Breath-holding spells are reflex events provoked by anger, frustration or pain, which makes the child cry incessantly.
  • Suddenly, the crying stops at full expiration, and the child becomes cyanotic or, rarely,
  • In some cases, he maylose consciousness and become hypotonic.
  • These events begin are rare before6 months of age, start around 1 year of age, peak at 2 years and abate by 5 years of age.
  • The typical history of a provoking event and stereotyped patternof events helps to distinguish it from seizures.
  • Parental reassurance & adequate handling of the event should be advised. The child is turned over to one side so that secretions can drain, and avoid picking up the child. A brief tactile stimulus is sometimes used to abort the episode if unduly prolonged.

choices.text: Refer the child to a pediatric psychologist
Start selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor treatment

questions.text: A school nurse called you to see a 6-year-old boy with school refusal. He is always crying after parental leave and refuses to stay in the classroom. The school nurse informed you that she tried her best during the last 4 weeks, and she met with the parents frequently. Of the following, the BEST action is to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Management of school refusal typically requires parent management training and family therapy, with school personnel involvement is always indicated; anxious children often require special attention from teachers, counsellors, or school nurses.

  • Parents who are coached to calmly send their child to school and to reward the child for each completed day of school are usually successful; in this scenario, this option has been used.
  • In cases of ongoing school refusal, referral to a child psychiatrist or psychologist is indicated.
  • SSRI treatment may be helpful.
  • Young children with affective symptoms have agood prognosis.

questions.text: A term baby with a birth weight of 3 kg was on exclusive breastfeeds. On day 5 of life, the child was found to weigh 2.4 kg. There was no history of apnea, vomiting or hypothermia. What could be the likely cause of weight loss in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • We know that every normal term neonate on breastfeeds can lose between 7-10% of birth weight in the 1stweek of life. This is a physiological phenomenon.
  • However, theweight loss in this case is 600 g in the 1st. This translates to (600/3000) X 100= 20% weight loss
  • Any weight loss >10% in term and more than 15% in preterm babies is pathological.
  • Most common cause of pathological weight loss in the early neonatal period is Dehydration, owing to inadequate breast feeds.
  • Ensuring adequate breastfeeds can easily take care of this condition.
  • Regarding other options, rememberthat CCF due to PDA will cause weight gain in neonates due to Na/H20 retention, not weight loss.
  • Metabolic disorderis unlikely without symptoms like vomiting or lethargy.
